DOMQuad.summary: A DOMQuad is a collection of four DOMPoints defining the corners of an arbitrary quadrilateral. Returning DOMQuads lets getBoxQuads() return accurate information even when arbitrary 2D or 3D transforms are present. It has a handy bounds attribute returning a DOMRectReadOnly for those cases where you just want an axis-aligned bounding rectangle.

DOMQuadDOMQuad.summary: The DOMQuad() constructor creates and returns a new object, given the values for some or all of its properties.

remarks.para: You can also create a DOMQuad by calling the or static function. These functions accept any object with the required parameters, including a , , or another DOMQuad.

DOMQuadFromQuad.summary: The fromQuad() static method of the interface returns a new DOMQuad object based on the provided set of coordinates in the shape of another DOMQuad object.

DOMQuadFromRect.summary: The fromRect() static method of the interface returns a new DOMQuad object based on the provided set of coordinates in the shape of a object.

DOMQuadGetBounds.summary:
The method
getBounds() returns a object representing the smallest rectangle that fully contains the DOMQuad object.
DOMQuadGetBounds.returns: A with the x, y, width, and height properties, defining the bounding box for the DOMQuad based on its corner coordinates.

DOMQuadP1.summary: The DOMQuad interface's p1 property holds the object that represents one of the four corners of the DOMQuad. When created from , it is the point (x, y).
DOMQuadP1.value: The object includes the following double-precision floating-point values:Each of these values is unrestricted, meaning that it is allowed to be infinite or invalid (that is, its value may be or ).

DOMQuadP2.summary: The DOMQuad interface's p2 property holds the object that represents one of the four corners of the DOMQuad. When created from , it is the point (x + width, y).
DOMQuadP2.value: The object includes the following double-precision floating-point values:Each of these values is unrestricted, meaning that it is allowed to be infinite or invalid (that is, its value may be or ).

DOMQuadP3.summary: The DOMQuad interface's p3 property holds the object that represents one of the four corners of the DOMQuad. When created from , it is the point (x + width, y + height).
DOMQuadP3.value: The object includes the following double-precision floating-point values:Each of these values is unrestricted, meaning that it is allowed to be infinite or invalid (that is, its value may be or ).

DOMQuadP4.summary: The DOMQuad interface's p4 property holds the object that represents one of the four corners of the DOMQuad. When created from , it is the point (x, y + height).
DOMQuadP4.value: The object includes the following double-precision floating-point values:Each of these values is unrestricted, meaning that it is allowed to be infinite or invalid (that is, its value may be or ).

DOMQuadToJSON.summary:
The method
toJSON() returns a
JSON representation of the DOMQuad object.
DOMQuadToJSON.returns:
A new object whose properties are set to the values in the
DOMQuad on which the method was called.
